body: File or directory names on Windows cannot end with a trailing dot. Probably we should reject them with an "invalid filename" error at an earlier stage.

> File or directory names on Windows cannot end with a trailing dot. Probably we should reject them with an "invalid filename" error at an earlier stage.

Hmm, I can sync such files/folders between my Windows and Android machines. They can be created using

```
md \\?\C:\testfolder.
echo>\\?\C:\testfile.
```

or even

```
echo>\\?\C:\NUL
```

Although more of a hack than anything else, all of them are happily synced.
Probably some of the APIs we use don't like them. They're not supposed to exist, after all. :)

Yeah, but I am not sure if this is really the reason for the error described here though. I can synchronise them in my systems, and Syncthing does not complain at all.

However, Android does not accept something like `test./test.`. Windows does. I think that this may be more of a file system related problem. Windows uses NTFS, while Android uses FAT.

I'm certain it's the reason, but whether it's because our mkdir does not work precisely the same way your shell `md \\?\etc` does or because the filesystem or OS or registry or something is different is unclear. It doesn't matter though because the root problem is that we're attempting to do something we shouldn't (create a directory with an unsupported name).

Yes, but judging by what is going on in Android, I have a feeling that this is caused by the (ex)FAT system, and will be a problem regardless of the OS.

Just for the record, this is what Syncthing on Android says:

```
2020-09-28 06:44:00 Puller (folder "xxx" (xxxxx-xxxx), item "temp./temp."): syncing: resurrecting parent dir: file does not exist
```
It's indeed also true that FAT does not support all the things you might wish of a filesystem even when running under non-Windows. That's a different sort of problem though.

All right. The problem, I guess, will mostly be limited to Android, where FAT is common.

However, I have just seen that in the commit you included all the different reserved names like `NUL`, etc. but what about names followed by extensions? I mean `NUL.txt`, `NUL.exe` and similar. These are also considered "illegal" in Windows, i.e. Windows Explorer is unable to operate on them.

From the MS link:

>Do not use the following reserved names for the name of a file:
>
>CON, PRN, AUX, NUL, COM1, COM2, COM3, COM4, COM5, COM6, COM7, COM8, COM9, LPT1, LPT2, LPT3, LPT4, LPT5, LPT6, LPT7, LPT8, and LPT9. **Also avoid these names followed immediately by an extension; for example, NUL.txt is not recommended**.

It is not mentioned there, but even with multiple extensions, the file/folder will still be illegal, e.g. `NUL.txt.txt` and so on. Basically, anything starting with those illegal names and immediately followed by a dot seems to also be illegal.
I didn't test the illegality, just went by the "is not recommended" which I felt was less strong than "do not use" for the rest of the description. Those should apparently also be removed, yes.

I am very sorry for writing again, but I just wanted to say that there is a loophole in the current handling of the invalid filenames.

Basically, if an invalid file, e.g. `CON`, already exists in the folder on both sides, Syncthing will happily mark both "Up to Date". This can happen when sharing the folder for the first time with pre-existing files on both sides, or after copying the file manually to the other side. Syncthing also accepts all invalid filenames when the folder is "Unshared".

Is this OK as it is, or should Syncthing also mark these as invalid?
I think that's fine. We try to prevent oddities. If you've managed to have pre-existing oddities you can keep them. :)

would be able to mark a specific file to not be synchronized ?
example pet.notsync.jpg
Please use the forum for questions
